issues.title: On the need for storage metrics
issues.author: giralt
issues.body: Explain why storage metrics are needed. If they are required, we should give an example. (This was asked by Me during IETF 121)

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: Discussion 11.20: Add example text.

issues.title: On other routing metrics
issues.author: giralt
issues.body: Explain if other "routing metrics" mentioned in IDR docs are relevant or if they can be referenced. (This was asked by Ketan during IETF 121.)

comments.author: muzixing
comments.body: We have a draft in IDR https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ll-idr-cats-bgp-extension-00, which defines the solution of using BGP for cats. In the basic mode, it uses the extensions in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-idr-5g-edge-service-metadata-24.  5G-edge draft defines a general mechanism with several TLVs. CATS may use some of them but not all.

comments.author: bpatient78
comments.body:
Hi, all, I've reviewed two drafts mentioned from Ketan, https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-idr-bgp-generic-metric/ and https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-lsr-flex-algo-bw-con-15.html#section-2 

The first draft is an extension of RFC 7311 AIGP which is a set of accumulated cost metrics used in IGP domain, to inter domain usage by leverging BGP extensions for generic metrics defined in the second draft. It names the new mechanism AMetric. 
Some should be noted that:

- these generic metrics typically refer to network metrics as described in Section 2 of draft-ietf-lsr-flex-algo-bw-con-15:
"The Traffic Engineering Default Metric is defined in [RFC5305] and [RFC3630] and the Min Unidirectional delay metric is defined in [RFC8570] and [RFC7471]. Other metrics, such as jitter, reliability, and fiscal cost may be helpful, depending on the traffic class."

- These two drafts are more on metric exposure and metric distribution rather than the definition of new metrics.
- As mentioned in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-idr-bgp-generic-metric/ , it keeps emphasizing accumulation which should be compared with aggregation that mentioned in our drafts. 
- Similarly, it has a definition on normalized bit(Section 5) and which component does normalization(Section 8), and the way to use this normalized value(Section 8 and 9). I think we should refer to this part when we consider to define our normalized CATS metrics.
- As Cheng mentioned above and also Lindar mentioned in the list, there are some other documents describing CATS related metrics and ways to exposure. We should also look into these docs and put them into the same discussion thread.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: Discussion 11.20: AIGP draft is not mature.

comments.author: muzixing
comments.body:
some info FYI.
[1]. https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/idr/?q=draft-ssangli-idr-bgp-generic-metric-aigp
[2]. https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ssangli-idr-bgp-generic-metric-aigp-08#section-13
[3]. https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/119/materials/slides-119-idr-sessa-1-1-generic-metric-for-the-aigp-attribute-00 
[4]. https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/idr/HmvVM33WIrzEJ87U5QkWGjfvvNY/
[5]. https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-idr-entropy-label/

issues.title: On L0 metrics for decision making
issues.author: giralt
issues.body: Should some of the L0 metrics be used for decision making?(This was asked from Haomian during IETF 121)

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: Discussion 11.20: L2 contains L1, L1 contains L0. It is already considered.

issues.title: On the normalization of L2 metrics
issues.author: giralt
issues.body:
Joel wrote on the mailing list:

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cats/_AR5_zq4eWs0a8sNfa7d4nvNRkg/

> I have  a question regarding section 3.3 of this draft.  That section 
> defines the L2 metrics, which I hope are the ones we will actually 
> communicate from servers to ingress edge devices.  The text says that 
> each service may have their own normalization method.  That makes 
> sense.  There was a question raised during the meeting that is separate 
> from that text, but related to it.  How do we envision independent 
> implementors of a given service will know how to normalize their metrics 
> such that the ingress edge device can compare the normalized metrics.  
> (I think it is achievable, I am just missing how we will do so.)

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: The service influences the traffic steering decisions of the network through the normalized metric. It does not matter how the service calculate the metric, as long as the metric is comparable.

comments.author: bpatient78
comments.body: Should we add a subsection for recommending a way for normalization? I think in CATS it is more important and more complex, since different components can do normalization. (BGP speaker, sevice contact instance, or edge cloud management system, at compute domain and network controller at network domain) They  may use different methods for normalization depending on what metrics they use.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: Discussion 11.20: more discussion needed.

issues.title: On energy and security metrics
issues.author: giralt
issues.body: Should some of security and green metrics be scoped whithin CATS metric? (This was asked by Julien during IETF 121)

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: I am not familiar with any security metric. Gree metric can be useful.

comments.author: bpatient78
comments.body:
I'm also not familiar with security metrics, from the  slide
![Uploading image.png…]()

It looks like these security capability information and status information are very hard to categorize, so I sugguest may be we should avoid security related metrics. 

For green metrics, let's keep an eye on how GREEN WG define on the metrics. If they only care about green metrics on network side, and they don't care IT green metrics(e.g., data center green metrics.) Maybe we can consider green metrics in CATS. But right now, I don't think we should include them in the next version.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: Discussion 11.20: put GREEN metric in L1. trigger discussion in ML.

comments.author: muzixing
comments.body: We also need to have the security metric. This will trigger more discussion as well

comments.author: muzixing
comments.body: Callback: Adding an energy metric in L1 may help. Money talks

issues.title: Unit of metrics in examples.
issues.author: muzixing
issues.body:
1. 
Though it is example. 
We should specify one data unit/format instead of providing two formats,  See below.

Integer or FP8, choose one. Also, we might not use GHZ as unit, may use MHZ? so that the format can be an integer?

Basic fields:
      Metric type: “compute type_CPU”
      Format: integer, FP8
      Bits occupation: 4 octets
Special fields:
      Frequency unit: GHZ
      Compute capabilities unit: FLOPs
Source:
      Direct measurement
Statistics:
      Mean


Same for Storage and Network, GB or GB/s seems a too big unit. Better to use a MB， MB/s to allow the data value as a integer instead of a FP8？ or  we can choose GB, GB/s， and make the value as a float type. 

2. what is the score in the example of L1 Metric definition ? suggest to delete it. unless we have good reason to have it.
3. same question to L2 metric, why do we have score?

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body:
1. I am fine with whatever units in the example.
2. I think the score in the example means the value. Like value in TLV.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: Discussion 11.20: Only keep one format in example. Follow DMTF. What is the basic fields, special fields? Need to check consistency of all example in the draft.

comments.author: muzixing
comments.body: Score is the value of the metric. We do not need a score as a new K:V

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: Discussion 11.20: add new field: unit.

issues.title: section 4.2.5 needs better wording
issues.author: muzixing
issues.body:
[4.2.5. ](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ysl-cats-metric-definition-02#section-4.2.5)[Considerations on the Sources of Metrics and the Statistics](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ysl-cats-metric-definition-02#name-considerations-on-the-source)
The sources of L1 metrics is normalized. Based on L0 metrics, service providers design their own algorithms to normalize metrics. For example, assigning different cost values to each raw metric and do summation. L1 metric do not need further statistical values.

it is confusing to me when reading the above text. We need to rewrite it?

comments.author: bpatient78
comments.body: For example？

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: Discuss 11.20: rewrite the first sentence by Kehan Yao. Jordi will review the section 4 in detail. Maybe create a term definition section.

issues.title: No service metrics defined yet
issues.author: luismcontreras
issues.body:
By now we are covering resource-related metrics (CPU, storage, etc).

I wonder if service-related metrics can be also part of the picture. For instance number of sessions, etc.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: This is a good suggestion. Number of sessions can help determine the load of a service instance.

comments.author: muzixing
comments.body: Will number of sessions impact the resource in the end? should we describe the final status of resources or a transit state of resource? I will like to avoid to use number of sessions. Because we can not tell how much resource is occupied by a session. Even they are not equal for each session.

comments.author: bpatient78
comments.body: Sometimes number of sessions is important, when it does not have a linear relationship with CPU resource occupation. Since handling different service sessions may take up different compute resources. In such case, maybe we should consider them, but it is very hard to give it cost when doing normalization.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: Discussion 11.20: sessions are inaccurate to measure the utilization.

issues.title: L2 metric: just one aggregated metric or one for compute and one for network?
issues.author: luismcontreras
issues.body: With the current definition of L2 metric, the generation of such L2 metric can only be performed on an element consolidating both network and compute metrics. That is, the C-PS (or the Ingress C-Forwader), according to the current framework definition. It could be maybe more practical if we can consider L2 metrics per domain so that both C-SMA and C-NMA can generate L2 metrics per domain that later on can be consolidated in C-PS (or the Ingress C-Forwader), but avoiding the burden of transmitting all the L1 metrics up to C-PS (or the Ingress C-Forwader).

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: My understanding of metric in this document is all about compute domain metric, not network domain metric.

comments.author: bpatient78
comments.body:
I think Luis's comment makes sense, we should consider separately when generating the L2 metrics. But will it be a L3 metric if these L2 metrics generated from different agents and domain. L2 from C-NMA is for path selection considering network domain metrics only. L2 from C-SMA is for instance selection considering compute domain metrics only. So can they be simply summed up at the Ingress(C-PS)? If not, will there be a simple derivation and generation of another value(L3 metric)?. I'm not recommending we should have a L3 abstraction, but try to understand such case. Welcome for discussion.:) 

> My understanding of metric in this document is all about compute domain metric, not network domain metric.

to Vincent, this document is about CATS metrics, so it will cover both network and compute domain, even if we may not define new network metrics, considering large amout of work in network metrics definition. Metrics in network domain is for the derivation of CATS metrics.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: By domain I mean the source of the metric. That is to say, the metric defined in this document comes from computing side, not network side. Is that correct?

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: Discussion @11.20: Do we need to separate the network domain metric and computing domain metric? They should follow the same absctration principle.

issues.title: Considerations on IANA registry and standard track of CATS metrics
issues.author: bpatient78
issues.body:
Hi co-authors,

I find that no matter ALTO cost metrics or IGP cost metrics, they all have IANA registries. 
Since CATS metrics are newly proposed and may further be officially referred by other SDOs like 3GPP, ORAN, etc.

I'm thinking if we could ask CATS AD and chairs to change the type of our draft to be standard track before adoption, and also maybe we should add some text in IANA considerations and apply for IANA registries when these metrics are stable.

How do you think?

Kehan

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: +1 for standard track.

comments.author: giralt
comments.body: I think this makes sense.

comments.author: muzixing
comments.body: agree. I proposed this idea long time ago, let's try it.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: Discussion 11.20: Move to standard track. IANA section only contains L2 metric.

comments.author: giralt
comments.body:
Hi Kehan, all:

Are you thinking that we should have IANA registries for fields in L0, L1 or L2 metrics? Could you show an example here so we can discuss in more concrete terms the approach? thanks!

comments.author: muzixing
comments.body: IANA may only focus on the Categories of L1 metrics, and only one L2 metric. MUST not define any IANA registries for L0 metrics.

reviews.author: muzixing
reviews.body: we can merge this PR when address my comment of " necessitates balancing "

comments.body: Introducing a definition of metrics necessitates balancing the following trade-off. necessitates? better to refine this sentence to easy reading.

I will argue the definition here. L2 can be generated from L0 directly as well? Logical and hierarchical layers of aggregation looks nice, but L1 is not required for L2. is it correct? An implementation can generate a L2 metric from L0 metrics without the L1 metrics
Doable. good suggestion.
much better in reading. Thanks.
nice figure! Thanks!

Thanks for your comments Chen. 

Is this comment just a question of style? If so, this one may seem better:

"Introducing a definition of metrics requires balancing the following trade-off:"
I am ok with adding that flexibility and allowing L2 metrics to directly use L0 metrics. I will update the text in my next update.

it looks good to me. I learn from Sue and other experts in IETF that we should use simple and clear words in writing standards, because the purpose of a standard is to let people understand easily and implement it :)
ok, thanks!
LGTM

```suggestion
Various considerations for metric definition are proposed in {{?I-D.du-cats-computing-modeling-description}}, which are useful for defining computing metrics. This document categorizes the relevant computing metrics for CATS into three levels based on their complexity and granularity, following the considerations outlined in {{?I-D.du-cats-computing-modeling-description}}.
```
The last sentence is duplicated.

```suggestion
- CPU: Base Frequency, boosted frequency, number of cores, core utilization ratio, memory bandwidth, memory size, memory utilization ratio, power consumption.
```
Base vs boosted. I assume the ultilization ratio means memory ultilization?

```suggestion
L1 metrics are organized into distinct categories, such as computing, networking, storage, and delay. Each L0 metric is classified into one of these categories. Within each category, a single L1 metric is computed using an *aggregation function* and normalized to a unitless score that represents the performance of resources according to that category. Potential categories include:
```
a resource or resources?
Accepted this comment, thanks.

I did not write these descriptions, but I think you are right. I would simply remove the word ratio (since utilization implies that already)

Accepted this update too.
Sounds good. I would like to further suggest using "the underlying resources". I will make that change and update the PR. Thanks.
Maybe it should be "This document categorizes the relevant computing metrics as well as network metrics for CATS..."
"through the protocol" I remember Med gave a comment previously, asking us to give an example on what protocol. So perhaps here we should add an example. "through the protocol(e.g., BGP)"

Good point. I pushed this change: https://github.com/VMatrix1900/draft-cats-metric-definition/pull/8/commits/529c28a141cab00daffa213de8e5da8ff8ed2222

Let me know if this addresses your comment, thanks.

I had misunderstood the original question. I agree with this comment, and pushed this change: https://github.com/VMatrix1900/draft-cats-metric-definition/pull/8/commits/5bba78918b1bcea6446906614f155de96b943296

comments.author: giralt
comments.body:
Hi Kehan @bpatient78 ,

Thanks for your comments. I think Adrian makes great comments in #15 but I think it is best that we address them in a separate PR dedicated to his comments, since there are quite a few number of comments there. This will help keep the conversations more organized.

If you agree, and since I think I resolved all the other comments, do you think we can go ahead and merge this PR? After we close this PR, then we can focus the next PR on Adrian's comments and address them all in one PR if possible.

Thanks.

I think there are some differences between nominal and direct measurement. From my side, nominal is kind of static values that can be pre settled or given by providers, for example, bandwidth. direct measurement refers to dynamic values which might change over time during computing service scheduling, for example, delay.
It makes sense.  Agree to delete SLA in this draft.

Hi Jordi, can you please give an example on how to use this untiless L0 score for deriving L1 & L2 metrics? This metric should have physical meanings, right? Otherwise the component which implements the normalization algorithms will not know how it can use this metric.
Should we provide normalization functions in this draft?

The fields and examples below looks good to me.  
For the question on whether to standardize them, it looks like L1 and L2 metrics also need these fields for representation.  So maybe we should standardize them, And also it relates to where the normalization should be implemented. If it's implemented in the CATS domain, then these fields should be recognized and propagated.  Look for more feedback.
I think we can.
OK, makes sense I will add direct measurement in the next commit.
I think we should address Adrian's comment on this figure.

please also look into the comments from Adrian on the metrics representation. I summarized his commets into follows:
* need to explain whether to encode floating point into the fields of packets.(section 4.1.1)
* If so, should provide examples as well as references for the use of floating points, for example FP8. (section 4.1.1)
* Consider more carefully on the field space for each unit. (section 4.1.2)
* Explain whether integers should be signed or unsigned. (section 4.2)
maybe remove storage capacity, but depends on the discussion in the interim meeting on whether we should include storage metrics or we should create a category for storage metrics.
Agree with the additional explanation on each field from the above. Thanks Jordi!

A unitless metric is just a specific type of metric, so I think that not allowing vendors to specify unitless L0 metrics could be too restrictive. For instance, a vendor/implementation may want to expose a metric that just grades the overall performance of a resource, from 1 to 5, with 5 being the highest performance. Allowing L0 metrics to also have the option to be unitless, would allow implementors to specify such type of metrics and not be forced to always use metrics that have units.

There was a nice discussion during the interim on storage:

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/minutes-interim-2025-cats-01-202501151300/#:~:text=%5BMed%5D%20On%20the%20storage%20part%2C%20do%20we%20have%20a%20case%20to%20illustrate%20how

In addition to the CDN case mentioned in the conversation, I think the case of distributed AI (e.g., federated learning) also requires storage, since the models can be quite large, and they require storing checkpoints in the storage. So let me suggest to keep storage. In a newer version, we can add the justification, alongside all the other metrics.

reviews.author: muzixing
reviews.body: Thanks for you contribution, Jordi! Please see my comments below.

comments.body: We can provide an example, like a weighted function, but no need to add any details.

It will be ok to have this as a common formatted info to describe a metric. However, in a protocol design, we may not need so much fields. A type can be mapped to the {format, length, unit, value, and level}. Type: {format, length, unit, value, and level}. For example, Type 0 is the L2 fully normalized metric, with length 4 bytes, no unit, value X, and format in Int32.  Type 1 is the L1 normalized categorized metric, with category of Computing, length 4 bytes, unit in GHZ, value X in format of floating. 

In a nutshell, it is ok to have a basic model like this, which can be encoded by YANG MODEL, xml, Jason, etc, but no need to require a protocol to have all fields in this model.
agree, hard to specify what is SLA here. delete it please
may rephrase the text to replace Next?
let's keep storage as a L1 metric.
why we have this? seems redundant with the above ones. Do we only have more explanation here comparing to the above model?
we do not need to discuss any L0 metrics, leave it to implementation. Not in the scope of this document.
Agreed. I added this in the same TODO and will address in a future PR. I want to avoid branching out too much in this PR.

See my comment here https://github.com/ietf-wg-cats/draft-ietf-cats-metric-definition/pull/12#issuecomment-2597486993, let's address Adrian's comments in another PR this way we keep things organized and avoid mixing several tickets in the same PR.

See my comment here https://github.com/ietf-wg-cats/draft-ietf-cats-metric-definition/pull/12#issuecomment-2597486993, let's address Adrian's comments in another PR this way we keep things organized and avoid mixing several tickets in the same PR.

Also, I updated the suggestion above to have 'directly measured' sources and included it in the latest commit.
Done, removed SLA from the draft.
Done, kept. Text can be improved in future iterations.

This, as it says above, adds more details. The table above is meant to be a quick reference table for ease of use. The follow up text is meant to provide a description in more detail. Tables are good at summarizing items, but they are not good for providing many details. Text separated from the table allows us to extend the descriptions, add more detail, and clarify specific properties or descriptions for each item.
Agreed, the text is just providing examples of L0 metrics (this was not included in this PR, but it was already there), it is not telling vendors how to implement them.
OK
ok
ok
ok

pulls.title: Try to address comments from Adrian
pulls.author: bpatient78
pulls.body: Try to address comments from Adrian, issue #15 , but there are still some points that need further discussions, especially in section 4. Some of them are labelled with <note: >

comments.author: muzixing
comments.body: I will be in another meeting for MWC, sorry that I can not join this meeting, Hang Shi will represent our team. Thanks.

Thanks for making the adjustments according to Adrian's feedback.

One comment is that I find it more appropriate to talk about "communication metrics" rather than "network metrics". A network is a specific object. Networks also could involve several devices, some of them not related to communication. The key properties here are compute and communication. So I find it more appropriate to talk about "compute metrics" and "communication metrics".

I feel that computing, networking and delay are metrics that operate at different levels (so it's like comparing apples to oranges). For instance, computing refers to a general class of metrics (CPU clock rate, tflops, etc.), but "delay" is a specific type of metric. Further, delay could be applicable to both compute and communication metrics, so it overlaps with them, confusing the taxonomy.

I like to think of metrics organized on three broad types of classes depending on the "state of data":

(1) Data can be processed using a compute resource.
(2) Data can be transferred using a communication resource.
(3) Data can be at rest (not being processed and not being transferred) by keeping it in a storage device.

This leads to 3 broad classes of metrics IMO:

(1) Compute metrics.
(2) Communication metrics.
(3) Storage metrics.

Delay is a specific property, so it does not belong to the same level of the above three classes. That is, delay could be applicable to compute and communication resources.
I am not sure about removing storage here, we need more discussion I think. See my comment above about the possible states of data (processed, transferred, at rest)

In the line above, suggest the following text/small improvements:

"This field provides additional details about the metrics, particularly if there is any pre-computation performed on the metrics before they are collected. It is useful for services that require specific statistics for service instance selection."

I suggest the following text/small improvements:

"The sources of L0 metrics can be nominal, directly measured, estimated, or aggregated. Nominal L0 metrics are initially provided by resource providers. Dynamic L0 metrics are measured or estimated during the service stage. Additionally, L0 metrics support aggregation when there are multiple service instances."

Nit: add space before parenthesis 

"number (FP8)"

suggest:

"It is named "delay_raw". The format should support both integer and FP8. Its unit is microseconds, and it occupies 4 octets. For example:"

I think the above paragraph is  a bit confusing. Could you clarify a bit the meaning of this sentence? thanks:

They are numbers after some ways of abstraction, but they can represent their type, in case that in some use cases, some specific types of metrics require more attention.
Sounds reasonable
Thanks for the improvement.
I think mine is the same as yours. The only difference is M0-4 pointing to M2.
Yes.  Need further discussion. Considering there is some storage related use cases added into the CATS uc & reqs doc. And also, please see comments above

Hi, Jordi, thanks for your further clarification on data-oriented classfication. In the third category you mentioned"storage device". Here "storage device", does it refer to a storage server or storage unit inside a server? And what do you think "memory" should belong to? Does it belong to compute metrics or storage metrics? because the word "process" itself is complicated to define. if following a Von Neumann pattern, then memory should be part of the "processing", right?

In terms of delay, yes, it doesn't belong to the three categories above. It's special, because it can be applied to describe metrics from other categories. For example, FLOPS, if it is multiplied by a delay, you can count the total number of operations. So I'm thinking if we can treat delay as well as any other metric that can be described by delay, can be a pair **<metric_1, delay>**. Even the storage metric can also be paired with delay to calculate how much space it will be occupied.  

The metric pair describes: 
* The capability of the object--<metric_1>
* How long it will be useful-- < delay >
* The total amount--< product of metric_1 and delay>  serves as a further factor for instance selection decision making 

Going back to the metric framework, L0 doesn't need to be classified. The only question is should we put delay at L1. Just as I have described, maybe we can put delay as a seperate class which can be paired with other classes. We may need some text to explain it. Do you think it reasonable?
Thanks for the improvement.
Thanks.
Thanks.

Hi Jordi, sorry for making it ambiguious, I think it's because I'm not a native English speaker. I try to explain a bit more.
"They are numbers after some ways of abstraction" --- means L1 metrics are normalized from L0 metrics.
"but they can represent their type" -- even though L1 metrics don't have unit, they still can be classied(compute, communication or storage)
"in case that in some use cases, some specific types of metrics require more attention." -- This sentence wants to explain why L1 metrics are meaningful, compared to why not just normalized all L0 metrics directly into the L2 metric. The reason I think is that the category of L1 metrics can be useful for instance selection.
+1 on communication metric.
Delay should has its own class. We need it because it can not be generated from Computing metrics or networking metrics directly. Therefore, a Delay as a category in L1 makes sense to me.
do not agree to remove storage metrics. Since this is an important metrics for some services.
communication / connectivity / network metrics? for further discussion in IETF 122. Need agreement on terms.
Yeah, they are semantically the same. Adrian's diagram seemed a bit more balanced :)
depending on metrics, normalized metrics, unsigned, just score from 0 - X.

Luis: provide some options, not solution-specific;
Jordi: will look through framework draft and then comment.

Thanks for explaining. Based on your description, I would suggest using this text (or similar):

"L1 metrics are normalized from L0 metrics. Although they don't have units, they can still be classified into types such as compute and communication. This classification is useful because it makes L1 metrics semantically meaningful."

I would suggest the following improvement on paragraph 87:

"Network resource metrics, as defined in documents such as RFC 9439, RFC 8912, and RFC 8911, have been in use in network systems for a long time. This document focuses on categorizing the relevant computing metrics for CATS into three levels based on their complexity and granularity."

Suggest the following improvement for line 120:

"L0 metrics serve as foundational data and do not require classification. They provide basic information that supports higher-level metrics, which will be detailed in the following sections."

As we discussed yesterday, the challenge with delay is that it is not a category at the same level as "compute" and "communication". If we classify it directly as an L1 metric, the taxonomy will appear ill-defined. For instance, how about bandwidth? and others?

Since delay is a property of both compute and communication resources and can be aggregated (e.g., end-to-end delay as the sum of all delays from all compute and communication resources along the path), yesterday we discussed incorporating a new L1 class called 'composed metric.' Within 'composed metrics,' we would include 'delay' (end-to-end delay, computed using the aggregation function 'sum of all delays along the path') and 'bandwidth' (end-to-end bandwidth, computed using the aggregation function 'minimum of all resource bandwidths along the path'). Therefore, the proposal is to have three L1 categories:

- Compute metric
- Communication metric
- Composed metric, under which we would have delay and bandwidth.
Yesterday we discussed the option of incorporating storage as a metric inside the compute side, since based on the von Neumann machine argument, storage (memory) is an integral part of compute.
s/weighted summary/weighted sum/
The title above seems slightly convoluted. Maybe I would simplify and just say "CATS Metric Fields"
Just curious, why latency cannot have a nominal value? For instance, a link (a wired cable) could have a nominal propagation delay value (vendor provided).
s/avarage/average

Suggest the following slightly improved text for line 350:

"L1 metrics are derived from the normalization of one or more L0 metrics. Service providers can design their own algorithms to normalize L0 metrics. For example, they might assign different cost values to each raw metric and perform a weighted summation."
For line 433, suggest: "Comparison between the Metric Levels"
yes. you're right, I will delete the last sentence in this graph.

Suggest improving line 435 as follows:

"Metrics are consolidated from L0 to L1 to L2, with different levels of abstraction meeting the requirements of various services. Table 1 provides a comparison among the metric levels."
s/weighted summation/weighted sum/
Thanks.

pulls.title: JRG Rev 20250521
pulls.author: giralt
pulls.body: This commit makes additional text improvements. No major changes on the flow, just focusing on grammar and clarity of the text.

comments.author: muzixing
comments.body: Generally，I am ok with the update. But, regarding adding service-related metric, we might need more discussion. So we can update this revision without this. And update one more time to add service-related metric in L1.
throughput and latency/delay also belong to composed metrics, should we limit them in just composed metrics? Or we define two types of these metric？
throughput and latency/delay also belong to composed metrics, should we limit them in just composed metrics? Or we define two types of these metric？
'aggregation' and others may be not mutually exclusive. It may co-exist with other sources, I think.
Should we define another service-related category, maybe in L1? Service-related metrics like Queries per second(QPS), tokens per second(TPS), can be normalized into these category.
"particularly L2", why only L2?

Why do we grouped these fields into "Basic fields" ?

And why the field "Source" is outside "Basic fields"?

Are we planning on standardizing the size of each field according to the following lines?
````
|Metric Type|Level|Format| Unit|Length| Value|Source|
    8bits    2bits  1bit  4bits  3bits 32bits  3bits
````
If so, then I think this should not go here in the examples section.

If not, then why do we need to show here examples of field lengths?
OK, I changed it to just communication throughput.
I agree. I updated the text to explicitly mention that they are non mutually exclusive.

It was there before I made the change, do you no longer want it to be L2 for the decision making process in this comment?

This was the text before: "when L2 metrics are used for making decisions"
Right now L1 metrics can be computing, communication, and composed metrics. Are you suggesting to add a 4th metric category?

Yes. Recently, we got some feedback from the CDN team in ChinaMobile(MIGU applications). Their applications usually grasp some kinds of these service related metrics for instance selection, health check, or monitoring. They told us these service-related metrics are useful. So beyond resource level metrics(computing, communication, and composed metrics), these service-related metrics are also worthy to be added. So I sugguest to add 4th metric category in L1.
Sorry. I got it. I thought it would preclude L1. But it does not. I think the current description is ok.

Previously I thought that field like "statistics" doesn't belong to some metric levels, like L1 and L2. So I set other mandatory fields to be basic fields. But you're right, we don't need to further group these fields into "basic fields", and "Source" can be treated the same as others.

I think we should standardize the size of each field for better guidance on the implementation and interoperobility.
But sure, if it's not good to show it in the example section, where do you think should it be placed? A new section on format?
I think this should be an example. If we need to standardize it, then I will avoid to use 2 bits, 1 bit as length of a field, too limited.
QPS, TPS look like L0 metrics. If we add a L1 Service-related category, what should be the name? is the category is independent with the existing categories?
